title: 103_hr364
content: The "Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993" amends the Small Business Act to ensure fair marketing conditions in the livestock and meat industry. It addresses issues like loan availability and competitive environments for businesses. The "Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993" aims to address unfair marketing conditions in the livestock and meat industry that hinder competition and the free flow of goods in commerce. It declares the policy to regulate commerce among states and foreign nations to eliminate these conditions without significantly impacting production or distribution. The "Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993" aims to regulate commerce among states and foreign nations to correct unfair marketing conditions in the livestock and meat industry. It defines key terms such as commerce, livestock, meat food products, meatpacker, meat marketer, and person. The "Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993" defines key terms related to the regulation of commerce in the livestock and meat industry, including meat marketer, person, and meatpacker engaged in commerce. It covers individuals, partnerships, corporations, and organized groups involved in the manufacturing or sale of meats or meat food products. The "Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993" sets regulations for meatpackers engaged in commerce, limiting the number of cattle, swine, and sheep they can slaughter at one location per week. The act applies to businesses with annual sales of at least $250,000. The "Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993" restricts meatpackers from owning or controlling livestock for more than 20 days before sale, and limits the number of cattle, swine, and sheep they can slaughter per week. The act applies to businesses with annual sales of at least $250,000. The "Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993" prohibits meatpackers from owning or controlling livestock for more than 20 days before sale. It also limits the number of cattle, swine, and sheep they can slaughter per week. The act applies to businesses with annual sales of at least $250,000. The "Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993" prohibits meatpackers from selecting the delivery date of livestock contracts beyond twenty consecutive calendar days. Violators may face fines up to $50,000 or more per head of slaughtered livestock. Sec. 6 states that the Act will be considered an antitrust law. Sec. 7 mentions that if any provision of the Act is held invalid, it will not affect the validity of the rest of the Act.
